Column Comment.0: FIELD STATION ID: unique identifier for the stratigraphic field station.
Column Comment.1: STRAT NAME SET IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the stratigraphic name set. Astratigraphic name set is an unordered collection of stratigraphic units, that may be inuse for a Lexicon, a geographic area, a project, a company etc.
Column Comment.2: STRATIGRAPHIC UNIT IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the stratigraphic unit.
Column Comment.3: INTERPRETATION IDENTIFIER:: a unique identifier added to enable a single stratunit to be identified more than once as part of a stratigraphic column. Multipleoccurances may occur for many reasons, including folding, faulting or a non-verticalinterpretation of the strat column.
Column Comment.4: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.5: AREA ID: Unique identifier for any named area
Column Comment.6: AREA TYPE: The type of area described, such as country, province, basin, project,business area etc.
Column Comment.7: AZIMUTH_NORTH_TYPE:FK to R_NORTH.NORTH_TYPE. The North referenceused in surveying to define angular measurements. E.g. True North, Magnetic North,Grid North, Astronomical North.
Column Comment.8: CERTIFIED INDICATOR: A yes / no flag indicating that the pick has been certified foruse and is of long term value.
Column Comment.9: CONFORMITY RELATION: A descriptor assigned to formation picks that identifiesthe type of conformity relationship that describes the surface that was picked. May beunconformity, disconformity, angular unconformity, conformable ro paraconformable.An unconformity is a substantial break or gap in the geologic record wher a rock unitis overlain by another that is not next in stratigraphic succession. Normally impliesuplift or erosion with loss of the previously formed strata.
Column Comment.10: DIP_ANGLE:The steepest angle of descent of a tilted planar feature, in degreesrelative to a horizontal plane. This is an interpreted value; it cannot be measured inthe wellbore. It must be combined with a dip direction, e.g. 35N and 35S are twodifferent dips.
Column Comment.11: DIP_DIRECTION:The downward quadrant direction of the dip: N, S, E, W.
Column Comment.12: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.13: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.14: FAULT_HEAVE:The distance of the horizontal component of displacement on thefault plane. This is an interpreted value; it cannot be measured in the wellbore.
Column Comment.15: FAULT_THROW:The distance of the vertical component of displacement on the faultplane. This is an interpreted value; it cannot be measured in the wellbore.
Column Comment.16: INTERPRETATION VERSION: a version number for the interpretation of the stratcolumn unit. Added to allow the same strat unit to be identified in more than oneinterpretation.
Column Comment.17: BUSINESS ASSOCIATE: Unique identifier for a business associate, such as aperson, company, regulatory agency, government or consortium.
Column Comment.18: LITHOLOGY: The major lithologic type. For example sandstone, limestone, dolomiteor shale.
Column Comment.19: MISSING_SECTION:The apparent thickness that is missing. It should be recorded asa length in the wellbore, not true thickness, to be consistent with pick depths.
Column Comment.20: MISSING_STRAT_TYPE:FK to a new reference table R_MISSING_STRAT_TYPE.The reason why a portion of a strat unit is missing. Examples: fault, unconformity,fold.
Column Comment.21: ORDINAL SEQUENCE NUMBER: sequence in which this unit occurs in the column,from surface to base
Column Comment.22: OVERTURNED INDICATOR: a yes / no flag indicating that the strat unit is part of anoverturned section and that the normal sequnce of occurrence is reversed.
Column Comment.23: PICK DATE: the date that the pick was made.
Column Comment.24: PICK LOCATION: identifies the location or type of formation (strat unit) pick. Forexample top, base or middle.
Column Comment.25: PICK QUALIFIER: This reference table describes a qualifier used to describe aformation pick. For example not logged, missing, estimated or uncertain depth.
Column Comment.26: PICK QUALIFIER REASON: The reason that a qualifier was added for a pick, suchas poor data, faulting, erosion.
Column Comment.27: PICK QUALITY: the quality of or degree of confidence in the pick that was made,such as poor, uncertain, good, excellent.
Column Comment.28: PICK VERSION TYPE: the type of version of pick that is given in an interpretationtable, such as working, final, proposed etc.
Column Comment.29: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.30: PREFERRED PICK INDICATOR: a yes / no flag indicating that for this unit, the pickis a preferred pick, and should be used for default mapping and calculations orreports.
Column Comment.31: REMARK: narrative remarks about the interpretation of the strat unit in the column.
Column Comment.32: REPEAT_SECTION:The apparent thickness that is repeated. It should be recordedas a length in the wellbore, not true thickness, to be consistent with pick depths.
Column Comment.33: REPEAT STRATIGRAPHIC OCCURRENCE NUMBER: A number identifying theoccurrence of a stratigraphic unit in the interpretation. Used to resolve multipleoccurrences of the same stratigraphic unit within the well section.
Column Comment.34: REPEAT STRATIGRAPHY TYPE: The reason the stratigraphic unit was picked twicein the same interpretation. Usually occurs because of horizontal or deviated drillingtechniques or as a result of faulting or folding.
Column Comment.35: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.36: SOURCE DOCUMENT: A list of documents that are used as the source for supplyingdata. Source documents may include government and regulatory forms, operatorreports or scout tickets, publications, news letters, books or jounals.
Column Comment.37: STRATIGRAPHIC INTERPRETATION METHOD: Interpretation method - surfacesample, sub-surface, logs, seismic, etc.
Column Comment.38: STRAT UNIT MEASURED DEPTH: Measured depth from the surface to the top ofthe picked formation.
Column Comment.39: STRAT UNIT MEASURED DEPTH ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE:
Column Comment.40: STRAT UNIT TRUE VERTICAL DEPTH: True vertical depth from the surface datumto the pick of the formation top.
Column Comment.41: STRIKE :The geographic bearing in azimuth degrees of a horizontal line (strike)representing the intersection of a planar feature (bed, fault, unconformity) with ahorizontal plane. This is an interpreted value; it cannot be measured in the wellbore.
Column Comment.42: APPLICATION NAME: Unique name code for the software application.
Column Comment.43: TRUE THICKNESS IND: A yes / no flag indicating that the measured distancerepresents true thickness, as opposed to apparent thickness. Y = True thickness.
Column Comment.44: TVD METHOD: This reference table defines the method used to determine the truevertical depth.
Column Comment.45: VERSION OBSERVATION NUMBER: a unique number indicating which version ofinterpetation this is. Each new version should be indicated with a new number.
Column Comment.46: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.47: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.48: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.49: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.50: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.51: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.52: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
